htmlEmbed:
Money in the MetaverseCondé Nast0/4/2022

Anna Wiener writes about the metaverse, and how the use of money is developing in a space that combines virtual reality, augmented reality, the Internet, entertainment experiences, gaming, and remote work.

letter from silicon valley, new yorker favorites, money, capitalism, technology, facebook, internet, video games, cryptocurrency, splitscreenimagerightfullbleed, inverted, web, tagsRead

</script><script></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"\n\n[#iframe: http://audm.herokuapp.com/player-embed?pub=newyorker&articleID=61cf28fd99931c4bc72a0273](100%x90)\n\n+++dropcap\n\nYears ago, while on vacation in the Northwest, my husband and I rented a room in the home of a middle-aged couple, one of whom had recently retired. The house was old, beautiful, and cozily laden with objects that signalled domestic inertia. It sat on a lush, wild sprawl of farmland that immediately inspired fantasies of leaving San Francisco and our tech jobs, foraging for mushrooms, administering to septic systems, and turning over soil.\n\n+++\n\nOne morning over breakfast, conversation shifted to our host’s retirement. He was glad to have more time at home with his wife and their dog. He was baking a lot. He was spending hours playing FarmVille.\n\n“FarmVille?” I asked, half awake, spreading honey over a slice of toast. Through the picture window, we could see mist rising from the evergreens. The dog nosed around in the vegetable beds. FarmVille, our host confirmed pleasantly—it was a game, a farming simulator, played by tens of millions of people on Facebook—before asking if we might be interested in some eggs. We were. The eggs were fresh. The sun was emerging. Our host seemed very happy with his lot.\n\nIt is hard to know what anyone else really wants, and I think of this man often. I thought of him most recently while watching Mark Zuckerberg deliver an hour-long presentation on Facebook’s rebrand—it is now called Meta—and its newfound focus on building the “metaverse”: a vast and integrated virtual world. Watching Zuckerberg stroll through a blandly monied virtual set, appointed, as if from a drop-down menu, with books and trinkets and unused-looking sports equipment, I wondered if there were people who wanted this, or would find this vision exciting. Then I reminded myself: FarmVille. I think it is useful, in attempts to forecast the future, to be humble about the enormous mystery of other people’s desires.\n\nIn recent months, the metaverse has been described as a kind of online place, combining virtual reality, augmented reality, the Internet, entertainment experiences, gaming, and remote work. The key idea is that, no matter what you’re doing in the metaverse, or where you are, your identities and assets will be multi-platform and transportable: you’ll be the same “you” at work and at leisure. As the concept of the metaverse has snaked into the discourse, predictions about it have seemed mainly to reflect the desires of the corporations that are setting the terms of the conversation. (The term “metaverse” itself, which has its origins in dystopian science fiction, has been aggressively promoted by companies with worlds to sell.) Reading about the metaverse, I’ve often had the uneasy feeling that I am taking something far too seriously—giving credence to the wrong things, internalizing the wrong logic—simply because a small number of world-historically wealthy people have told me to.\n\nWhat they are saying is incredible, not least because it is entirely speculative. They suggest that the metaverse will be a “massively scaled and interoperable network of real-time rendered 3D virtual worlds which can be experienced synchronously and persistently by an effectively unlimited number of users” (the venture capitalist Matthew Ball). They offer that it might enable companies “to embed computing into the real world and to embed the real world into computing” (the Microsoft C.E.O., Satya Nadella)—and that it could make “the virtual world more real and the real world more rich with virtual experiences” (the Tencent C.E.O., Pony Ma). Tim Sweeney, the C.E.O. of Epic Games, has said that the metaverse may be “a multi-trillion-dollar part of the world economy”; Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, thinks that it could create “a new economy that is larger than our current economy.” The over-all point is that it will be simultaneously a place for connection, community, and so on, and also a forum for transaction and extraction. For its makers, the metaverse will be stuffed with money—in every dimension, all the way down.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nIf the metaverse materializes, it will probably look and behave like a video game, at least for a little while. For millions of people, video games already serve as everyday, immersive virtual experiences; gaming companies provide infrastructure for Hollywood films, spatial visualizations, and live performances. Aesthetically, the metaverse could have the gauzy realism of 2019’s “[The Lion King](https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/07/29/does-the-lion-king-need-cgi),” the anesthetized cheerfulness of The Sims, the pixel-art graphics of the sixteen-bit era, or any other vibe. Physically, it will probably be accessed through headgear—V.R. headsets, A.R. glasses—or simply a computer screen. Financially, it could look something like FarmVille, in which players spent millions of dollars on virtual windmills, fertilizer, farm animals, and water, tending to what Alenda Y. Chang, an associate professor of film and media studies at U.C. Santa Barbara, has called an “ecologically absurd” landscape, in which dying crops could be revived by “unwither” spray, and sheep produced wool sweaters after eating tomatoes.\n\n+++\n\nThe gaming industry’s business models tend to evolve on the heels of technological development. In the early two-thousands, premium games were sold as standalone products; like blockbuster films, they came with large marketing budgets, vivid advertising campaigns, and hotly anticipated release dates, around which the bulk of revenue was collected. But as personal computers grew faster and more powerful and the Internet became more reliable and ubiquitous, the model began to shift. Some games were no longer stored on disks or cartridges but in the cloud; often, people accessed them not on gaming consoles but through their smartphones. Massively multiplayer online games, such as World of Warcraft, brought small-scale, in-app purchases—known as microtransactions—into the mainstream. Microtransactions were most common in “free-to-play” games. These cost nothing to download, but grew increasingly complex—and, crucially, more fun—with every additional expenditure. Now game companies could charge for new levels, new features, and new things to buy, pushed directly to users’ devices.\n\nAlexander Bernevega and Alex Gekker, researchers in Amsterdam, have [described](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/15554120211014151) this transition as the “assetization” of top-tier video games—a shift toward what Jathan Sadowski has called “[new rentier capitalism](https://onezero.medium.com/landlord-2-0-techs-new-rentier-capitalism-a0bfe491b463).” The future of the industry, Bernevega and Gekker write, will be one of “fully assetized gaming,” in which “gamers will own neither the games nor the consoles” but pay for seasonal “battle passes” or owe subscription fees. At the same time, the logic of ownership will live on inside the games themselves, in the form of customizable skins for avatars, character attire weapons, tools, and so on, acquired through microtransactions. “This is what makes the modern blockbuster game a highly productive asset,” the authors write. “By combining the rent-based and commodity-based models,” the games “are able to continually draw income.”\n\nAs in-game economies grew, they generated robust black markets for virtual items, with players buying and selling everything from ordinary game elements (armor, weapons, gold) to the equivalent of collectibles (a limited-edition party hat). Because players were accustomed to spending real money on virtual goods—or, in some cases, real money on digital currency, which could be spent on virtual goods—these black markets could be lucrative. Real-money trading, or R.M.T., began with one-to-one exchanges on sites like eBay, but was quickly scaled up and professionalized. Some players, usually in places with limited economic opportunity, took up gaming full-time in order to rack up in-game loot, treasure, and bonuses, selling those assets for profit, outside the game, to other players—a practice known as “gold-farming.”\n\nIn 2004, the president of Internet Gaming Entertainment—a virtual-asset-trading startup, established in 2001, that relied on the labor of low-wage players—estimated that the market for virtual goods and services was about eight hundred and eighty million dollars a year. By 2009, as many as a million “farmers” worked in China, many of them in tightly packed, open-plan computer labs, under conditions that were often compared, in the media, to sweatshops. In 2011, the *Guardian* reported that prisoners at a Chinese labor camp were being made to play online multiplayer games, “to build up credits that prison guards would then trade for real money.” Reading about people who played games for profit reminded me of “Games of Empire: Global Capitalism and Video Games,” a seminal work in video-games studies published in 2009, by Nick Dyer-Witheford and Greig de Peuter, academics working in media studies. The authors argue that video games are the “paradigmatic media of Empire”—a totalizing regime of “planetary, militarized hypercapitalism.”\n\nMassively multiplayer online role-playing games fell out of fashion in the early twenty-tens, eBay banned the sale of virtual goods, pushing it to smaller, more ephemeral Web sites and marketplaces. Game developers, sometimes under regulatory pressure, tried to crack down on off-platform sales, which were almost always against their end-user license agreements and terms of service anyway. But in recent years, real-money trading has seen a minor resurgence. Old School RuneScape and Tibia, online multiplayer games set in fantasy worlds, have attracted players from [Venezuela](https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2019/11/21/venezuelas-paper-currency-is-worthless-so-its-people-seek-virtual-gold), who have found that their in-game currencies are more valuable and stable than the bolívar. (The games are popular in part because of their retro graphics, which can run well on older computers with slow internet connections.) In 2019, when Venezuela was hit with widespread power outages, there was an immediate economic crisis in Old School RuneScape.\n\nAbove-board video-game marketplaces, meanwhile, have become more abundant and varied. These days, people spend more than [eighty billion dollars](https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-tech-seeks-its-next-fortune-in-the-metaverse-11636459200) a year on virtual goods sold in video games. Game-studies scholars have long argued that gaming allows players to experiment with new identities and modes of being: “Virtual games simulate identities as citizen-soldiers, free-agent workers, cyborg adventurers, and corporate criminals,” Dyer-Witheford and de Peuter write. “Virtual play trains flexible personalities for flexible jobs, shapes subjects for militarized markets, and makes becoming a neoliberal subject fun.” Virtual worlds, it seems, also train players to be eager, expectant, and constant consumers.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nGames reflect their creators’ societies and circumstances. FarmVille, in which players obsessively managed capricious fiefdoms, was launched in 2009, and has had two sequels. In 2011, FarmVille players spent an estimated hundred million dollars on virtual goods; the writer Cory Doctorow later [characterized](http://locusmag.com/2018/01/cory-doctorow-persuasion-adaptation-and-the-arms-race-for-your-attention/) it as “an unregulated, low-yield casino game.” In retrospect, the game looks like an artifact of Silicon Valley’s post-recession startup scene, which flourished during a transitional, confusing time when smartphones weren’t yet ubiquitous and uneasy borders still held between online and offline life. The game was played on Facebook, and revolved around virtual crops that died without constant attention. It relied on the defining features of its technological moment—social-media networks, data collection, reëngagement hacks, user-generated content, and native advertising. FarmVille’s success, the artist and designer A.J. Patrick [Liszkiewicz](https://www.berfrois.com/2010/10/cultivated-play-farmville/) has written, depended on its adoption of social-media logic—it entangled users “in a web of social obligations.”\n\n+++\n\nThe metaverse, if it takes off, will reflect its cultural and technological moment, too. Taking cues from today’s tech ecosystem, it will probably be privatized, centralized, and financialized, with rampant artificial scarcity. Players of FarmVille were not digital natives; players of games like Fortnite and Minecraft almost certainly are, and, in the metaverse, will be the target audience for companies selling digital skins, virtual trinkets, and cloud-based space. Some vocal proponents of “web3”—an as-yet unrealized idea for the Internet’s next phase, based on visions for a decentralized, blockchain-based digital substrate—have fixed their gaze on the metaverse, seeing it as an opportunity for epochal transformation. (Arguments in favor of web3 are frequently made using utopian rhetoric—democratization, decentralization, transformation, freedom, revolution, and so on—that elevates, or obscures, what would otherwise be a financial conversation.) We don’t yet know if cryptocurrency and the blockchain will have anything to do with what Microsoft, Meta, Roblox, or Tencent are building (although the torrent of venture capital flowing into cryptocurrency-related companies is notable). But the future importance of money in the metaverse seems indisputable. Meta-life will probably involve a reimagination of financial life and, possibly, a shift in our existing social hierarchies and institutions. “Many of today’s dominant visions for the future of money are unlinked from the political and territorial structures of nationhood,” the media scholar Lana Swartz writes, in her book “[New Money: How Payment Became Social Media](https://www.amazon.com/New-Money-Payment-Became-Social/dp/0300233221),” published in 2020. “All of these visions are, on some level, postdemocracy fantasies.”\n\nA new crop of video games, categorized as “play-to-earn,” might give us a sense of where the metaverse is headed. Players of such games are often rewarded with native cryptocurrency—that is, with the game’s version of Bitcoin or Ethereum. Unlike FarmVille’s Farm Bucks or RuneScape’s gold pieces, which were in-game only, these new cryptocurrencies can be traded, off-platform, for other cryptocurrencies or government-issued money. Currently, the most prominent play-to-earn game is Axie Infinity, which is frequently compared to the game Pokémon. Characters in Axie Infinity, called Axies, are [N.F.T.s](https://www.newyorker.com/tech/annals-of-technology/how-beeple-crashed-the-art-world), or “non-fungible tokens,” which serve as certificates of ownership for stoned-looking cartoon axolotls. By winning battles with their Axies, or selling them to others, players rack up tokens of Smooth Love Potion (S.L.P.), and “governance” tokens called Axie Infinity Shards (A.X.S.); today, on cryptocurrency exchanges, a single S.L.P. token is valued at about three cents, and an A.X.S. token is worth about ninety-three dollars. During the pandemic, people in the Philippines have taken to playing Axie Infinity [professionally](https://restofworld.org/2021/axie-infinity/), finding it more lucrative than local employment. “We believe in a future where work and play become one,” the game’s F.A.Q. states. ‌“We believe in empowering our players and giving them economic opportunities.”\n\nRecently, on a podcast produced by the venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, Jeff Zirlin, a co-founder of Sky Mavis, the Vietnamese gaming company that makes Axie Infinity, used the same extravagant rhetoric to describe the game’s appeal. “What we’ve built is not just the gaming community,” he said. “It is, in many ways, a nation where people have shared cultural values.” In this nation, it seemed, any distinctions between culture and finance had collapsed. Some critics note a sense in which Axie Infinity’s revenue model is like a ponzi scheme: to start, players are required to purchase three Axie N.F.T.s, which can cost anywhere from a hundred to a thousand dollars, and this props up the value of current players’ Axies. If new players stop signing up, the internal economy may sputter and crash. Even so, any cash flow problems might be mitigated, for a time, by venture funding: Sky Mavis recently raised more than a hundred and fifty million dollars in venture capital, at a three-billion-dollar valuation; the funding round was led by Andreessen Horowitz, which was an early investor in Zynga, the creator of FarmVille. Even when the game changes, certain strategies—and players—stay the same. (“Gaming is going to be a key way in which the next hundreds of millions of users onboard into crypto,” Arianna Simpson, an Andreessen Horowitz partner, noted, on the podcast.)\n\nListening, I wondered, Could I make this my life? Banking dashboards, cryptocurrency wallets, ledgers and spreadsheets. I tried to imagine myself in a corporate-owned and venture-funded metaverse: a virtual axolotl in a virtual sweater, writing for a virtual magazine in a virtual office, hemorrhaging virtual money. I might covet the Gen Z copy-editor’s avatar, and hope that readers would invest in N.F.T.s of my work. I could be paid in CondéCoin, with a cut going to Meta or Minecraft or Microsoft, whatever corporation or game was my virtual landlord. Weekends would be spent at the arcade, or the casino. My husband and I would go on virtual vacations to virtual worlds, stay with virtual hosts who played virtual games set on virtual farms. I could play to earn—and earn, and earn. I could have everything I wanted, and nothing at all.\n\n","articleSection":"letter from silicon valley","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Anna class="ArticlePageContentBackGround-eCrksR jtzOWH"><div class="LightboxWrapper-bgKpQJ jYtxfY"><div class="ArticlePageChunksContent-hqHLaf cyochf"><div data-testid="ArticlePageChunks" class="ArticlePageChunks-lglntq hOuAQM"><div class="GridWrapper-vNBSO jMumET grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-kRgPDq DBpfE grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buSdEM PibmB grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-ctnerm irSTVw body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><figure data-testid="IframeEmbed" class="IframeEmbedWrapper-sc-fgNRtM dEBJBh iframe-embed"><div data-testid="IframeEmbedContainer" class="IframeEmbedContainer-hMYtlV CezEt"><div class="MessageBannerWrapper-fxbXMh bORRYQ ConsentBannerWrapper-fjNDIs jwFidD" data-testid="message-banner"><div class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt MessageBannerContent-gbiOzb eTiIvU nukNt JXzIW"><h4 class="ConsentBannerTitle-gRDCkr hvsKJu">Content</h4><p>This content can also be viewed on the site it <a href="http://audm.herokuapp.com/player-embed?pub=newyorker&articleID=61cf28fd99931c4bc72a0273" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noreferrer" class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt BaseLink-gZQqBA ConsentBannerLink-godHGj eTiIvU nukNt iYqWCq">originates</a> from.</p></div></div></div></figure><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading paywall">Years ago, while on vacation in the Northwest, my husband and I rented a room in the home of a middle-aged couple, one of whom had recently retired. The house was old, beautiful, and cozily laden with objects that signalled domestic inertia. It sat on a lush, wild sprawl of farmland that immediately inspired fantasies of leaving San Francisco and our tech jobs, foraging for mushrooms, administering to septic systems, and turning over soil.</p><p class="paywall">One morning over breakfast, conversation shifted to our host’s retirement. He was glad to have more time at home with his wife and their dog. He was baking a lot. He was spending hours playing FarmVille.</p><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-kkMeXf hBFNZw consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div><p class="paywall">“FarmVille?” I asked, half awake, spreading honey over a slice of toast. Through the picture window, we could see mist rising from the evergreens. The dog nosed around in the vegetable beds. FarmVille, our host confirmed pleasantly—it was a game, a farming simulator, played by tens of millions of people on Facebook—before asking if we might be interested in some eggs. We were. The eggs were fresh. The sun was emerging. Our host seemed very happy with his lot.</p><p class="paywall">It is hard to know what anyone else really wants, and I think of this man often. I thought of him most recently while watching Mark Zuckerberg deliver an hour-long presentation on Facebook’s rebrand—it is now called Meta—and its newfound focus on building the “metaverse”: a vast and integrated virtual world. Watching Zuckerberg stroll through a blandly monied virtual set, appointed, as if from a drop-down menu, with books and trinkets and unused-looking sports equipment, I wondered if there were people who wanted this, or would find this vision exciting. Then I reminded myself: FarmVille. I think it is useful, in attempts to forecast the future, to be humble about the enormous mystery of other people’s desires.</p><p class="paywall">In recent months, the metaverse has been described as a kind of online place, combining virtual reality, augmented reality, the Internet, entertainment experiences, gaming, and remote work. The key idea is that, no matter what you’re doing in the metaverse, or where you are, your identities and assets will be multi-platform and transportable: you’ll be the same “you” at work and at leisure. As the concept of the metaverse has snaked into the discourse, predictions about it have seemed mainly to reflect the desires of the corporations that are setting the terms of the conversation. (The term “metaverse” itself, which has its origins in dystopian science fiction, has been aggressively promoted by companies with worlds to sell.) Reading about the metaverse, I’ve often had the uneasy feeling that I am taking something far too seriously—giving credence to the wrong things, internalizing the wrong logic—simply because a small number of world-historically wealthy people have told me to.</p><p class="paywall">What they are saying is incredible, not least because it is entirely speculative. They suggest that the metaverse will be a “massively scaled and interoperable network of real-time rendered 3D virtual worlds which can be experienced synchronously and persistently by an effectively unlimited number of users” (the venture capitalist Matthew Ball). They offer that it might enable companies “to embed computing into the real world and to embed the real world into computing” (the Microsoft C.E.O., Satya Nadella)—and that it could make “the virtual world more real and the real world more rich with virtual experiences” (the Tencent C.E.O., Pony Ma). Tim Sweeney, the C.E.O. of Epic Games, has said that the metaverse may be “a multi-trillion-dollar part of the world economy”; Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, thinks that it could create “a new economy that is larger than our current economy.” The over-all point is that it will be simultaneously a place for connection, community, and so on, and also a forum for transaction and extraction. For its makers, the metaverse will be stuffed with money—in every dimension, all the way down.</p><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading paywall">If the metaverse materializes, it will probably look and behave like a video game, at least for a little while. For millions of people, video games already serve as everyday, immersive virtual experiences; gaming companies provide infrastructure for Hollywood films, spatial visualizations, and live performances. Aesthetically, the metaverse could have the gauzy realism of 2019’s “<a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/07/29/does-the-lion-king-need-cgi">The Lion King</a>,” the anesthetized cheerfulness of The Sims, the pixel-art graphics of the sixteen-bit era, or any other vibe. Physically, it will probably be accessed through headgear—V.R. headsets, A.R. glasses—or simply a computer screen. Financially, it could look something like FarmVille, in which players spent millions of dollars on virtual windmills, fertilizer, farm animals, and water, tending to what Alenda Y. Chang, an associate professor of film and media studies at U.C. Santa Barbara, has called an “ecologically absurd” landscape, in which dying crops could be revived by “unwither” spray, and sheep produced wool sweaters after eating tomatoes.</p><p class="paywall">The gaming industry’s business models tend to evolve on the heels of technological development. In the early two-thousands, premium games were sold as standalone products; like blockbuster films, they came with large marketing budgets, vivid advertising campaigns, and hotly anticipated release dates, around which the bulk of revenue was collected. But as personal computers grew faster and more powerful and the Internet became more reliable and ubiquitous, the model began to shift. Some games were no longer stored on disks or cartridges but in the cloud; often, people accessed them not on gaming consoles but through their smartphones. Massively multiplayer online games, such as World of Warcraft, brought small-scale, in-app purchases—known as microtransactions—into the mainstream. Microtransactions were most common in “free-to-play” games. These cost nothing to download, but grew increasingly complex—and, crucially, more fun—with every additional expenditure. Now game companies could charge for new levels, new features, and new things to buy, pushed directly to users’ devices.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-1 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">Alexander Bernevega and Alex Gekker, researchers in Amsterdam, have <a href="https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/15554120211014151">described</a> this transition as the “assetization” of top-tier video games—a shift toward what Jathan Sadowski has called “<a data-offer-url="https://onezero.medium.com/landlord-2-0-techs-new-rentier-capitalism-a0bfe491b463" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://onezero.medium.com/landlord-2-0-techs-new-rentier-capitalism-a0bfe491b463"}" href="https://onezero.medium.com/landlord-2-0-techs-new-rentier-capitalism-a0bfe491b463" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">new rentier capitalism</a>.” The future of the industry, Bernevega and Gekker write, will be one of “fully assetized gaming,” in which “gamers will own neither the games nor the consoles” but pay for seasonal “battle passes” or owe subscription fees. At the same time, the logic of ownership will live on inside the games themselves, in the form of customizable skins for avatars, character attire weapons, tools, and so on, acquired through microtransactions. “This is what makes the modern blockbuster game a highly productive asset,” the authors write. “By combining the rent-based and commodity-based models,” the games “are able to continually draw income.”</p><div class="Container-imGeBO ftlPuP"></div><p class="paywall">As in-game economies grew, they generated robust black markets for virtual items, with players buying and selling everything from ordinary game elements (armor, weapons, gold) to the equivalent of collectibles (a limited-edition party hat). Because players were accustomed to spending real money on virtual goods—or, in some cases, real money on digital currency, which could be spent on virtual goods—these black markets could be lucrative. Real-money trading, or R.M.T., began with one-to-one exchanges on sites like eBay, but was quickly scaled up and professionalized. Some players, usually in places with limited economic opportunity, took up gaming full-time in order to rack up in-game loot, treasure, and bonuses, selling those assets for profit, outside the game, to other players—a practice known as “gold-farming.”</p><p class="paywall">In 2004, the president of Internet Gaming Entertainment—a virtual-asset-trading startup, established in 2001, that relied on the labor of low-wage players—estimated that the market for virtual goods and services was about eight hundred and eighty million dollars a year. By 2009, as many as a million “farmers” worked in China, many of them in tightly packed, open-plan computer labs, under conditions that were often compared, in the media, to sweatshops. In 2011, the <em>Guardian</em> reported that prisoners at a Chinese labor camp were being made to play online multiplayer games, “to build up credits that prison guards would then trade for real money.” Reading about people who played games for profit reminded me of “Games of Empire: Global Capitalism and Video Games,” a seminal work in video-games studies published in 2009, by Nick Dyer-Witheford and Greig de Peuter, academics working in media studies. The authors argue that video games are the “paradigmatic media of Empire”—a totalizing regime of “planetary, militarized hypercapitalism.”</p><p class="paywall">Massively multiplayer online role-playing games fell out of fashion in the early twenty-tens, eBay banned the sale of virtual goods, pushing it to smaller, more ephemeral Web sites and marketplaces. Game developers, sometimes under regulatory pressure, tried to crack down on off-platform sales, which were almost always against their end-user license agreements and terms of service anyway. But in recent years, real-money trading has seen a minor resurgence. Old School RuneScape and Tibia, online multiplayer games set in fantasy worlds, have attracted players from <a data-offer-url="https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2019/11/21/venezuelas-paper-currency-is-worthless-so-its-people-seek-virtual-gold" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2019/11/21/venezuelas-paper-currency-is-worthless-so-its-people-seek-virtual-gold"}" href="https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2019/11/21/venezuelas-paper-currency-is-worthless-so-its-people-seek-virtual-gold" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Venezuela</a>, who have found that their in-game currencies are more valuable and stable than the bolívar. (The games are popular in part because of their retro graphics, which can run well on older computers with slow internet connections.) In 2019, when Venezuela was hit with widespread power outages, there was an immediate economic crisis in Old School RuneScape.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buSdEM gKfJBS grid--item grid-layout__aside"><aside class="PersistentAsideWrapper-OTtoN iRwLFv persistent-aside" style="position:absolute;top:auto;height:auto" data-testid="PersistentAsideWrapper"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-euhCxU hyXuto sticky-box"><div class="StickyBoxPrimary-fEgDcn dFVkFO sticky-box__primary"><div class="AdWrapper-fFweuL dIvDeZ ad ad--rail"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--rail" data-node-id="4tdy2r"></div></div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-kkMeXf hBFNZw consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--display-rail" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--display-rail"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><div class="StickyBoxPlaceholder-jNQMsI laMCLq"></div></div></aside></div></div><div class="RowWrapper-egDQBE hVsKfd full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-fFweuL dIvDeZ ad ad--mid-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="9tkt9"></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-vNBSO jMumET grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-kRgPDq DBpfE grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buSdEM PibmB grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-ctnerm irSTVw body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">Above-board video-game marketplaces, meanwhile, have become more abundant and varied. These days, people spend more than <a data-offer-url="https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-tech-seeks-its-next-fortune-in-the-metaverse-11636459200" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-tech-seeks-its-next-fortune-in-the-metaverse-11636459200"}" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-tech-seeks-its-next-fortune-in-the-metaverse-11636459200" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">eighty billion dollars</a> a year on virtual goods sold in video games. Game-studies scholars have long argued that gaming allows players to experiment with new identities and modes of being: “Virtual games simulate identities as citizen-soldiers, free-agent workers, cyborg adventurers, and corporate criminals,” Dyer-Witheford and de Peuter write. “Virtual play trains flexible personalities for flexible jobs, shapes subjects for militarized markets, and makes becoming a neoliberal subject fun.” Virtual worlds, it seems, also train players to be eager, expectant, and constant consumers.</p><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading paywall">Games reflect their creators’ societies and circumstances. FarmVille, in which players obsessively managed capricious fiefdoms, was launched in 2009, and has had two sequels. In 2011, FarmVille players spent an estimated hundred million dollars on virtual goods; the writer Cory Doctorow later <a data-offer-url="http://locusmag.com/2018/01/cory-doctorow-persuasion-adaptation-and-the-arms-race-for-your-attention/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"http://locusmag.com/2018/01/cory-doctorow-persuasion-adaptation-and-the-arms-race-for-your-attention/"}" href="http://locusmag.com/2018/01/cory-doctorow-persuasion-adaptation-and-the-arms-race-for-your-attention/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">characterized</a> it as “an unregulated, low-yield casino game.” In retrospect, the game looks like an artifact of Silicon Valley’s post-recession startup scene, which flourished during a transitional, confusing time when smartphones weren’t yet ubiquitous and uneasy borders still held between online and offline life. The game was played on Facebook, and revolved around virtual crops that died without constant attention. It relied on the defining features of its technological moment—social-media networks, data collection, reëngagement hacks, user-generated content, and native advertising. FarmVille’s success, the artist and designer A.J. Patrick <a data-offer-url="https://www.berfrois.com/2010/10/cultivated-play-farmville/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.berfrois.com/2010/10/cultivated-play-farmville/"}" href="https://www.berfrois.com/2010/10/cultivated-play-farmville/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Liszkiewicz</a> has written, depended on its adoption of social-media logic—it entangled users “in a web of social obligations.”</p><p class="paywall">The metaverse, if it takes off, will reflect its cultural and technological moment, too. Taking cues from today’s tech ecosystem, it will probably be privatized, centralized, and financialized, with rampant artificial scarcity. Players of FarmVille were not digital natives; players of games like Fortnite and Minecraft almost certainly are, and, in the metaverse, will be the target audience for companies selling digital skins, virtual trinkets, and cloud-based space. Some vocal proponents of “web3”—an as-yet unrealized idea for the Internet’s next phase, based on visions for a decentralized, blockchain-based digital substrate—have fixed their gaze on the metaverse, seeing it as an opportunity for epochal transformation. (Arguments in favor of web3 are frequently made using utopian rhetoric—democratization, decentralization, transformation, freedom, revolution, and so on—that elevates, or obscures, what would otherwise be a financial conversation.) We don’t yet know if cryptocurrency and the blockchain will have anything to do with what Microsoft, Meta, Roblox, or Tencent are building (although the torrent of venture capital flowing into cryptocurrency-related companies is notable). But the future importance of money in the metaverse seems indisputable. Meta-life will probably involve a reimagination of financial life and, possibly, a shift in our existing social hierarchies and institutions. “Many of today’s dominant visions for the future of money are unlinked from the political and territorial structures of nationhood,” the media scholar Lana Swartz writes, in her book “<a data-offer-url="https://www.amazon.com/New-Money-Payment-Became-Social/dp/0300233221" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.amazon.com/New-Money-Payment-Became-Social/dp/0300233221"}" href="https://www.amazon.com/New-Money-Payment-Became-Social/dp/0300233221" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">New Money: How Payment Became Social Media</a>,” published in 2020. “All of these visions are, on some level, postdemocracy fantasies.”</p><p class="paywall">A new crop of video games, categorized as “play-to-earn,” might give us a sense of where the metaverse is headed. Players of such games are often rewarded with native cryptocurrency—that is, with the game’s version of Bitcoin or Ethereum. Unlike FarmVille’s Farm Bucks or RuneScape’s gold pieces, which were in-game only, these new cryptocurrencies can be traded, off-platform, for other cryptocurrencies or government-issued money. Currently, the most prominent play-to-earn game is Axie Infinity, which is frequently compared to the game Pokémon. Characters in Axie Infinity, called Axies, are <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/tech/annals-of-technology/how-beeple-crashed-the-art-world">N.F.T.s</a>, or “non-fungible tokens,” which serve as certificates of ownership for stoned-looking cartoon axolotls. By winning battles with their Axies, or selling them to others, players rack up tokens of Smooth Love Potion (S.L.P.), and “governance” tokens called Axie Infinity Shards (A.X.S.); today, on cryptocurrency exchanges, a single S.L.P. token is valued at about three cents, and an A.X.S. token is worth about ninety-three dollars. During the pandemic, people in the Philippines have taken to playing Axie Infinity <a data-offer-url="https://restofworld.org/2021/axie-infinity/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://restofworld.org/2021/axie-infinity/"}" href="https://restofworld.org/2021/axie-infinity/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">professionally</a>, finding it more lucrative than local employment. “We believe in a future where work and play become one,” the game’s F.A.Q. states. ‌“We believe in empowering our players and giving them economic opportunities.”</p><p class="paywall">Recently, on a podcast produced by the venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, Jeff Zirlin, a co-founder of Sky Mavis, the Vietnamese gaming company that makes Axie Infinity, used the same extravagant rhetoric to describe the game’s appeal. “What we’ve built is not just the gaming community,” he said. “It is, in many ways, a nation where people have shared cultural values.” In this nation, it seemed, any distinctions between culture and finance had collapsed. Some critics note a sense in which Axie Infinity’s revenue model is like a ponzi scheme: to start, players are required to purchase three Axie N.F.T.s, which can cost anywhere from a hundred to a thousand dollars, and this props up the value of current players’ Axies. If new players stop signing up, the internal economy may sputter and crash. Even so, any cash flow problems might be mitigated, for a time, by venture funding: Sky Mavis recently raised more than a hundred and fifty million dollars in venture capital, at a three-billion-dollar valuation; the funding round was led by Andreessen Horowitz, which was an early investor in Zynga, the creator of FarmVille. Even when the game changes, certain strategies—and players—stay the same. (“Gaming is going to be a key way in which the next hundreds of millions of users onboard into crypto,” Arianna Simpson, an Andreessen Horowitz partner, noted, on the podcast.)</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-2 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">Listening, I wondered, Could I make this my life? Banking dashboards, cryptocurrency wallets, ledgers and spreadsheets. I tried to imagine myself in a corporate-owned and venture-funded metaverse: a virtual axolotl in a virtual sweater, writing for a virtual magazine in a virtual office, hemorrhaging virtual money. I might covet the Gen Z copy-editor’s avatar, and hope that readers would invest in N.F.T.s of my work. I could be paid in CondéCoin, with a cut going to Meta or Minecraft or Microsoft, whatever corporation or game was my virtual landlord. Weekends would be spent at the arcade, or the casino. My husband and I would go on virtual vacations to virtual worlds, stay with virtual hosts who played virtual games set on virtual farms. I could play to earn—and earn, and earn. I could have everything I wanted, and nothing at all.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buSdEM gKfJBS grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-euhCxU hyXuto sticky-box"><div Wiener writes about the metaverse, and how the use of money is developing in a space that combines virtual reality, augmented reality, the Internet, entertainment experiences, gaming, and remote work.","head.keywords":"money,capitalism,technology,facebook,internet,video games,cryptocurrency","head.og.type":"article","head.robots":"index, follow, max-image-preview:large","head.title":"Money in the Metaverse | The New Yorker","tenant":"the-new-yorker","head.social.title":"Money in the Metaverse","head.social.description":"In a virtual world full of virtual goods, finance could get weird.","head.promo.dek":"In a virtual world full of virtual goods, finance could get weird.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"\n\n[#iframe: http:\u002F\u002Faudm.herokuapp.com\u002Fplayer-embed?pub=newyorker&articleID=61cf28fd99931c4bc72a0273](100%x90)\n\n+++dropcap\n\nYears ago, while on vacation in the Northwest, my husband and I rented a room in the home of a middle-aged couple, one of whom had recently retired. The house was old, beautiful, and cozily laden with objects that signalled domestic inertia. It sat on a lush, wild sprawl of farmland that immediately inspired fantasies of leaving San Francisco and our tech jobs, foraging for mushrooms, administering to septic systems, and turning over soil.\n\n+++\n\nOne morning over breakfast, conversation shifted to our host’s retirement. He was glad to have more time at home with his wife and their dog. He was baking a lot. He was spending hours playing FarmVille.\n\n“FarmVille?” I asked, half awake, spreading honey over a slice of toast. Through the picture window, we could see mist rising from the evergreens. The dog nosed around in the vegetable beds. FarmVille, our host confirmed pleasantly—it was a game, a farming simulator, played by tens of millions of people on Facebook—before asking if we might be interested in some eggs. We were. The eggs were fresh. The sun was emerging. Our host seemed very happy with his lot.\n\nIt is hard to know what anyone else really wants, and I think of this man often. I thought of him most recently while watching Mark Zuckerberg deliver an hour-long presentation on Facebook’s rebrand—it is now called Meta—and its newfound focus on building the “metaverse”: a vast and integrated virtual world. Watching Zuckerberg stroll through a blandly monied virtual set, appointed, as if from a drop-down menu, with books and trinkets and unused-looking sports equipment, I wondered if there were people who wanted this, or would find this vision exciting. Then I reminded myself: FarmVille. I think it is useful, in attempts to forecast the future, to be humble about the enormous mystery of other people’s desires.\n\nIn recent months, the metaverse has been described as a kind of online place, combining virtual reality, augmented reality, the Internet, entertainment experiences, gaming, and remote work. The key idea is that, no matter what you’re doing in the metaverse, or where you are, your identities and assets will be multi-platform and transportable: you’ll be the same “you” at work and at leisure. As the concept of the metaverse has snaked into the discourse, predictions about it have seemed mainly to reflect the desires of the corporations that are setting the terms of the conversation. (The term “metaverse” itself, which has its origins in dystopian science fiction, has been aggressively promoted by companies with worlds to sell.) Reading about the metaverse, I’ve often had the uneasy feeling that I am taking something far too seriously—giving credence to the wrong things, internalizing the wrong logic—simply because a small number of world-historically wealthy people have told me to.\n\nWhat they are saying is incredible, not least because it is entirely speculative. They suggest that the metaverse will be a “massively scaled and interoperable network of real-time rendered 3D virtual worlds which can be experienced synchronously and persistently by an effectively unlimited number of users” (the venture capitalist Matthew Ball). They offer that it might enable companies “to embed computing into the real world and to embed the real world into computing” (the Microsoft C.E.O., Satya Nadella)—and that it could make “the virtual world more real and the real world more rich with virtual experiences” (the Tencent C.E.O., Pony Ma). Tim Sweeney, the C.E.O. of Epic Games, has said that the metaverse may be “a multi-trillion-dollar part of the world economy”; Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, thinks that it could create “a new economy that is larger than our current economy.” The over-all point is that it will be simultaneously a place for connection, community, and so on, and also a forum for transaction and extraction. For its makers, the metaverse will be stuffed with money—in every dimension, all the way down.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nIf the metaverse materializes, it will probably look and behave like a video game, at least for a little while. For millions of people, video games already serve as everyday, immersive virtual experiences; gaming companies provide infrastructure for Hollywood films, spatial visualizations, and live performances. Aesthetically, the metaverse could have the gauzy realism of 2019’s “[The Lion King](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2019\u002F07\u002F29\u002Fdoes-the-lion-king-need-cgi),” the anesthetized cheerfulness of The Sims, the pixel-art graphics of the sixteen-bit era, or any other vibe. Physically, it will probably be accessed through headgear—V.R. headsets, A.R. glasses—or simply a computer screen. Financially, it could look something like FarmVille, in which players spent millions of dollars on virtual windmills, fertilizer, farm animals, and water, tending to what Alenda Y. Chang, an associate professor of film and media studies at U.C. Santa Barbara, has called an “ecologically absurd” landscape, in which dying crops could be revived by “unwither” spray, and sheep produced wool sweaters after eating tomatoes.\n\n+++\n\nThe gaming industry’s business models tend to evolve on the heels of technological development. In the early two-thousands, premium games were sold as standalone products; like blockbuster films, they came with large marketing budgets, vivid advertising campaigns, and hotly anticipated release dates, around which the bulk of revenue was collected. But as personal computers grew faster and more powerful and the Internet became more reliable and ubiquitous, the model began to shift. Some games were no longer stored on disks or cartridges but in the cloud; often, people accessed them not on gaming consoles but through their smartphones. Massively multiplayer online games, such as World of Warcraft, brought small-scale, in-app purchases—known as microtransactions—into the mainstream. Microtransactions were most common in “free-to-play” games. These cost nothing to download, but grew increasingly complex—and, crucially, more fun—with every additional expenditure. Now game companies could charge for new levels, new features, and new things to buy, pushed directly to users’ devices.\n\nAlexander Bernevega and Alex Gekker, researchers in Amsterdam, have [described](https:\u002F\u002Fjournals.sagepub.com\u002Fdoi\u002Ffull\u002F10.1177\u002F15554120211014151) this transition as the “assetization” of top-tier video games—a shift toward what Jathan Sadowski has called “[new rentier capitalism](https:\u002F\u002Fonezero.medium.com\u002Flandlord-2-0-techs-new-rentier-capitalism-a0bfe491b463).” The future of the industry, Bernevega and Gekker write, will be one of “fully assetized gaming,” in which “gamers will own neither the games nor the consoles” but pay for seasonal “battle passes” or owe subscription fees. At the same time, the logic of ownership will live on inside the games themselves, in the form of customizable skins for avatars, character attire weapons, tools, and so on, acquired through microtransactions. “This is what makes the modern blockbuster game a highly productive asset,” the authors write. “By combining the rent-based and commodity-based models,” the games “are able to continually draw income.”\n\nAs in-game economies grew, they generated robust black markets for virtual items, with players buying and selling everything from ordinary game elements (armor, weapons, gold) to the equivalent of collectibles (a limited-edition party hat). Because players were accustomed to spending real money on virtual goods—or, in some cases, real money on digital currency, which could be spent on virtual goods—these black markets could be lucrative. Real-money trading, or R.M.T., began with one-to-one exchanges on sites like eBay, but was quickly scaled up and professionalized. Some players, usually in places with limited economic opportunity, took up gaming full-time in order to rack up in-game loot, treasure, and bonuses, selling those assets for profit, outside the game, to other players—a practice known as “gold-farming.”\n\nIn 2004, the president of Internet Gaming Entertainment—a virtual-asset-trading startup, established in 2001, that relied on the labor of low-wage players—estimated that the market for virtual goods and services was about eight hundred and eighty million dollars a year. By 2009, as many as a million “farmers” worked in China, many of them in tightly packed, open-plan computer labs, under conditions that were often compared, in the media, to sweatshops. In 2011, the *Guardian* reported that prisoners at a Chinese labor camp were being made to play online multiplayer games, “to build up credits that prison guards would then trade for real money.” Reading about people who played games for profit reminded me of “Games of Empire: Global Capitalism and Video Games,” a seminal work in video-games studies published in 2009, by Nick Dyer-Witheford and Greig de Peuter, academics working in media studies. The authors argue that video games are the “paradigmatic media of Empire”—a totalizing regime of “planetary, militarized hypercapitalism.”\n\nMassively multiplayer online role-playing games fell out of fashion in the early twenty-tens, eBay banned the sale of virtual goods, pushing it to smaller, more ephemeral Web sites and marketplaces. Game developers, sometimes under regulatory pressure, tried to crack down on off-platform sales, which were almost always against their end-user license agreements and terms of service anyway. But in recent years, real-money trading has seen a minor resurgence. Old School RuneScape and Tibia, online multiplayer games set in fantasy worlds, have attracted players from [Venezuela](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.economist.com\u002Fthe-americas\u002F2019\u002F11\u002F21\u002Fvenezuelas-paper-currency-is-worthless-so-its-people-seek-virtual-gold), who have found that their in-game currencies are more valuable and stable than the bolívar. (The games are popular in part because of their retro graphics, which can run well on older computers with slow internet connections.) In 2019, when Venezuela was hit with widespread power outages, there was an immediate economic crisis in Old School RuneScape.\n\nAbove-board video-game marketplaces, meanwhile, have become more abundant and varied. These days, people spend more than [eighty billion dollars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wsj.com\u002Farticles\u002Fbig-tech-seeks-its-next-fortune-in-the-metaverse-11636459200) a year on virtual goods sold in video games. Game-studies scholars have long argued that gaming allows players to experiment with new identities and modes of being: “Virtual games simulate identities as citizen-soldiers, free-agent workers, cyborg adventurers, and corporate criminals,” Dyer-Witheford and de Peuter write. “Virtual play trains flexible personalities for flexible jobs, shapes subjects for militarized markets, and makes becoming a neoliberal subject fun.” Virtual worlds, it seems, also train players to be eager, expectant, and constant consumers.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nGames reflect their creators’ societies and circumstances. FarmVille, in which players obsessively managed capricious fiefdoms, was launched in 2009, and has had two sequels. In 2011, FarmVille players spent an estimated hundred million dollars on virtual goods; the writer Cory Doctorow later [characterized](http:\u002F\u002Flocusmag.com\u002F2018\u002F01\u002Fcory-doctorow-persuasion-adaptation-and-the-arms-race-for-your-attention\u002F) it as “an unregulated, low-yield casino game.” In retrospect, the game looks like an artifact of Silicon Valley’s post-recession startup scene, which flourished during a transitional, confusing time when smartphones weren’t yet ubiquitous and uneasy borders still held between online and offline life. The game was played on Facebook, and revolved around virtual crops that died without constant attention. It relied on the defining features of its technological moment—social-media networks, data collection, reëngagement hacks, user-generated content, and native advertising. FarmVille’s success, the artist and designer A.J. Patrick [Liszkiewicz](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.berfrois.com\u002F2010\u002F10\u002Fcultivated-play-farmville\u002F) has written, depended on its adoption of social-media logic—it entangled users “in a web of social obligations.”\n\n+++\n\nThe metaverse, if it takes off, will reflect its cultural and technological moment, too. Taking cues from today’s tech ecosystem, it will probably be privatized, centralized, and financialized, with rampant artificial scarcity. Players of FarmVille were not digital natives; players of games like Fortnite and Minecraft almost certainly are, and, in the metaverse, will be the target audience for companies selling digital skins, virtual trinkets, and cloud-based space. Some vocal proponents of “web3”—an as-yet unrealized idea for the Internet’s next phase, based on visions for a decentralized, blockchain-based digital substrate—have fixed their gaze on the metaverse, seeing it as an opportunity for epochal transformation. (Arguments in favor of web3 are frequently made using utopian rhetoric—democratization, decentralization, transformation, freedom, revolution, and so on—that elevates, or obscures, what would otherwise be a financial conversation.) We don’t yet know if cryptocurrency and the blockchain will have anything to do with what Microsoft, Meta, Roblox, or Tencent are building (although the torrent of venture capital flowing into cryptocurrency-related companies is notable). But the future importance of money in the metaverse seems indisputable. Meta-life will probably involve a reimagination of financial life and, possibly, a shift in our existing social hierarchies and institutions. “Many of today’s dominant visions for the future of money are unlinked from the political and territorial structures of nationhood,” the media scholar Lana Swartz writes, in her book “[New Money: How Payment Became Social Media](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FNew-Money-Payment-Became-Social\u002Fdp\u002F0300233221),” published in 2020. “All of these visions are, on some level, postdemocracy fantasies.”\n\nA new crop of video games, categorized as “play-to-earn,” might give us a sense of where the metaverse is headed. Players of such games are often rewarded with native cryptocurrency—that is, with the game’s version of Bitcoin or Ethereum. Unlike FarmVille’s Farm Bucks or RuneScape’s gold pieces, which were in-game only, these new cryptocurrencies can be traded, off-platform, for other cryptocurrencies or government-issued money. Currently, the most prominent play-to-earn game is Axie Infinity, which is frequently compared to the game Pokémon. Characters in Axie Infinity, called Axies, are [N.F.T.s](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Ftech\u002Fannals-of-technology\u002Fhow-beeple-crashed-the-art-world), or “non-fungible tokens,” which serve as certificates of ownership for stoned-looking cartoon axolotls. By winning battles with their Axies, or selling them to others, players rack up tokens of Smooth Love Potion (S.L.P.), and “governance” tokens called Axie Infinity Shards (A.X.S.); today, on cryptocurrency exchanges, a single S.L.P. token is valued at about three cents, and an A.X.S. token is worth about ninety-three dollars. During the pandemic, people in the Philippines have taken to playing Axie Infinity [professionally](https:\u002F\u002Frestofworld.org\u002F2021\u002Faxie-infinity\u002F), finding it more lucrative than local employment. “We believe in a future where work and play become one,” the game’s F.A.Q. states. ‌“We believe in empowering our players and giving them economic opportunities.”\n\nRecently, on a podcast produced by the venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, Jeff Zirlin, a co-founder of Sky Mavis, the Vietnamese gaming company that makes Axie Infinity, used the same extravagant rhetoric to describe the game’s appeal. “What we’ve built is not just the gaming community,” he said. “It is, in many ways, a nation where people have shared cultural values.” In this nation, it seemed, any distinctions between culture and finance had collapsed. Some critics note a sense in which Axie Infinity’s revenue model is like a ponzi scheme: to start, players are required to purchase three Axie N.F.T.s, which can cost anywhere from a hundred to a thousand dollars, and this props up the value of current players’ Axies. If new players stop signing up, the internal economy may sputter and crash. Even so, any cash flow problems might be mitigated, for a time, by venture funding: Sky Mavis recently raised more than a hundred and fifty million dollars in venture capital, at a three-billion-dollar valuation; the funding round was led by Andreessen Horowitz, which was an early investor in Zynga, the creator of FarmVille. Even when the game changes, certain strategies—and players—stay the same. (“Gaming is going to be a key way in which the next hundreds of millions of users onboard into crypto,” Arianna Simpson, an Andreessen Horowitz partner, noted, on the podcast.)\n\nListening, I wondered, Could I make this my life? Banking dashboards, cryptocurrency wallets, ledgers and spreadsheets. I tried to imagine myself in a corporate-owned and venture-funded metaverse: a virtual axolotl in a virtual sweater, writing for a virtual magazine in a virtual office, hemorrhaging virtual money. I might covet the Gen Z copy-editor’s avatar, and hope that readers would invest in N.F.T.s of my work. I could be paid in CondéCoin, with a cut going to Meta or Minecraft or Microsoft, whatever corporation or game was my virtual landlord. Weekends would be spent at the arcade, or the casino. My husband and I would go on virtual vacations to virtual worlds, stay with virtual hosts who played virtual games set on virtual farms. I could play to earn—and earn, and earn. I could have everything I wanted, and nothing at all.\n\n","articleSection":"letter from silicon valley","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Anna Her new essay collection, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” will be published in December.","bio":"Judith Thurman began contributing to *The New Yorker* in 1987 and became a staff writer in 2000. She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” is forthcoming in 2022.","shortBio":null,"socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"},"__typename":"Contributor"}],"channel":{"slug":"a-critic-at-large","name":"A Critic at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Her most recent book is “[Home\u002FLand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FHome-Land-Memoir-Departure-Return-ebook\u002Fdp\u002FB094GP8RFX).”","bio":"Rebecca Mead joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 1997. She has profiled many subjects, among them [Lin-Manuel Miranda](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F09\u002Fhamiltons), [Margaret Atwood](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2017\u002F04\u002F17\u002Fmargaret-atwood-the-prophet-of-dystopia), [Ivo van Hove](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F26\u002Ftheatre-laid-bare), [Joanna Hogg](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2019\u002F05\u002F20\u002Fjoanna-hoggs-self-portrait-of-a-lady), and [Mary Beard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2014\u002F09\u002F01\u002Ftroll-slayer). She is the author of several books, including “[My Life in Middlemarch](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FMy-Life-Middlemarch-Rebecca-Mead\u002Fdp\u002F0307984761\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=3SIGQJCFK3J9R&keywords=my+life+in+middlemarch&qid=1645866525&sprefix=my+life+in+middle%2Caps%2C223&sr=8-1),” a New York *Times* best-seller, and “[Home\u002FLand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FHome-Land-Memoir-Departure-Return\u002Fdp\u002F0525658718\u002Fref=sr_1_6?dchild=1&keywords=%22rebecca+mead%22&qid=1622313922&sr=8-6).” She has served as a McGraw Professor of Writing at Princeton University and was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, in 2020. Her new essay collection, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” will be published in December.","bio":"Judith Thurman began contributing to *The New Yorker* in 1987 and became a staff writer in 2000. She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” is forthcoming in 2022.","shortBio":null,"socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"},"__typename":"Contributor"}],"channel":{"slug":"a-critic-at-large","name":"A Critic at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Her new essay collection, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” will be published in December.","bio":"Judith Thurman began contributing to *The New Yorker* in 1987 and became a staff writer in 2000. She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” is forthcoming in 2022.","shortBio":null,"socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"},"__typename":"Contributor"}],"channel":{"slug":"a-critic-at-large","name":"A Critic at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Her new essay collection, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” will be published in December.","bio":"Judith Thurman began contributing to *The New Yorker* in 1987 and became a staff writer in 2000. She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” is forthcoming in 2022.","shortBio":null,"socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"},"__typename":"Contributor"}],"channel":{"slug":"a-critic-at-large","name":"A Critic at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A She has profiled many subjects, among them [Lin-Manuel Miranda](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F09\u002Fhamiltons), [Margaret Atwood](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2017\u002F04\u002F17\u002Fmargaret-atwood-the-prophet-of-dystopia), [Ivo van Hove](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F26\u002Ftheatre-laid-bare), [Joanna Hogg](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2019\u002F05\u002F20\u002Fjoanna-hoggs-self-portrait-of-a-lady), and [Mary Beard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2014\u002F09\u002F01\u002Ftroll-slayer). She is the author of several books, including “[My Life in Middlemarch](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FMy-Life-Middlemarch-Rebecca-Mead\u002Fdp\u002F0307984761\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=3SIGQJCFK3J9R&keywords=my+life+in+middlemarch&qid=1645866525&sprefix=my+life+in+middle%2Caps%2C223&sr=8-1),” a New York *Times* best-seller, and “[Home\u002FLand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FHome-Land-Memoir-Departure-Return\u002Fdp\u002F0525658718\u002Fref=sr_1_6?dchild=1&keywords=%22rebecca+mead%22&qid=1622313922&sr=8-6).” She has served as a McGraw Professor of Writing at Princeton University and was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, in 2020.
